'''Byther Smith''' (born April 17, 1933, [[Monticello, Mississippi|Monticello]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[musician]], noted for his gritty style and uncompromising delivery.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|last=Dahl |first=Bill |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/byther-smith-mn0000939457 |title=Byther Smith - Music Biography, Credits and Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1933-04-17 |accessdate=2013-03-10}}</ref>

==Career==
Born the sixth oldest of seven children, Smith immigrated to [[Chicago]] in the mid 1950s. Although he worked for a candy company, Smith's real passion was music. He played [[Double bass|bass]] for a three-piece [[jazz]] [[combo]] for a few years, but he eventually got a spot playing [[rhythm guitar]] for [[Otis Rush]]. In the early 1960s, Smith began to take the guitar more seriously and learned from [[J. B. Lenoir]], [[Robert Lockwood, Jr.]], and [[Hubert Sumlin]].<ref name="AMG"/>

After years playing in clubs all over the [[United States]] and the world, a [[demo tape]] Smith [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] became the [[album]] ''Tell Me How You Like It'', released by the [[Texas]] based Grits [[record label]]. His next release in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] was ''Addressing The Nation with The Blues'' for [[JSP Records]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X
| page= 167}}</ref>  In 1995, Smith retired from his job at Economy Folding Box Company after twenty-five years, allowing him to focus fully on music.

[[Delmark Records]] boss [[Bob Koester]] observed, "There's a mellowness there that is disappearing in all but [[B.B. King]]".<ref name="russell"/>

Smith still records and tours frequently.<ref name="AMG"/>

==Family==
Byther Smith is a first [[cousin]] of fellow blues musician and Monticello native, [[J. B. Lenoir]].<ref name="AMG"/>
